dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Apple's App Store. Does anyone really care if they charge developers a cut? Like, seriously?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Apple's App Store. Does anyone really care if they charge developers a cut? Like, seriously?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, actually. The Supreme Court just, like, cleared the way for a huge antitrust suit against them because of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, actually. The Supreme Court just, like, cleared the way for a huge antitrust suit against them because of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but isn't that just Spotify and Netflix complaining? Big companies fighting big companies, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but isn't that just Spotify and Netflix complaining? Big companies fighting big companies, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, no. It started with, uh, four iPhone owners, back in 2011. They're saying those fees mean we pay more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, no. It started with, uh, four iPhone owners, back in twenty eleven. They're saying those fees mean we pay more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. But Apple said, like, consumers can't sue them, only the app developers, right? That makes sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. But Apple said, like, consumers can't sue them, only the app developers, right? That makes sense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit. The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Kavanaugh, though. Justice Kavanaugh, in a 5-4 decision, he basically said Apple was trying to draw this "arbitrary and unprincipled line" to get out of trouble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kavanaugh, though. Justice Kavanaugh, in a five to four decision, he basically said Apple was trying to draw this arbitrary and unprincipled line to get out of trouble.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so they can sue. But what does that even mean? Is my Uber suddenly going to be cheaper?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so they can sue. But what does that even mean? Is my Uber suddenly going to be cheaper?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It could. The argument is that the 30% commission, or even the 15%, gets passed on to you. A Yale study, um, backed that up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It could. The argument is that the thirty percent commission, or even the fifteen percent, gets passed on to you. A Yale study, um, backed that up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers. That fee also is at the heart of the dispute that rose to the Supreme Court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds like a lot of fuss over, what, a few extra cents on an app? Apple said most apps are free anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds like a lot of fuss over, what, a few extra cents on an app? Apple said most apps are free anyway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the implications are huge, though. This isn't just about Apple. This could affect Google, Amazon, any platform that, uh, runs an app store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the implications are huge, though. This isn't just about Apple. This could affect Google, Amazon, any platform that, uh, runs an app store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, the entire digital economy? Seems a bit much for an app fee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, the entire digital economy? Seems a bit much for an app fee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, well, Apple's App Store pulls in billions. Billions, like, $3.7 billion last quarter alone, just from services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, well, Apple's App Store pulls in billions. Billions, like, three point seven dollars billion last quarter alone, just from services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter, according to market researcher Sensor Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but developers have made, what, like $120 billion over the years? So it's not all bad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but developers have made, what, like one hundred twenty dollars billion over the years? So it's not all bad.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples app store has been a significant source of revenue for developers, who received about $120 billion over the last 11 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not all bad for developers. But Spotify's CEO, he called Apple a "player and referee" who, um, "deliberately disadvantages" other apps.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not all bad for developers. But Spotify's C E O, he called Apple a player and referee who, um, deliberately disadvantages other apps.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Apple's just, like, "we'll prevail in court." So, big shrug from them, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Apple's just, like, we'll prevail in court. So, big shrug from them, I guess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple issued a statement, saying its confident that it will prevail in court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, publicly. But anonymous execs, uh, are apparently worried about the "repercussions for aggressive market strategies." This is a big deal, like, for everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, publicly. But anonymous execs, uh, are apparently worried about the repercussions for aggressive market strategies. This is a big deal, like, for everyone.
